content.title: Acute Aortic Occlusion
content.definition: Sudden thrombotic or embolic occlusion of the infrarenal aorta causing bilateral acute limb ischemia, often with severe hemodynamic compromise. A vascular emergency with high mortality (30-50%) requiring immediate intervention.

key_concepts.description: Saddle embolus (large embolus lodging at aortic bifurcation from cardiac source); thrombosis of severely atherosclerotic/aneurysmal aorta; thrombosis of aortic graft; aortic dissection with malperfusion
Large embolus (usually from atrial fibrillation or MI) lodges at aortic bifurcation; bilateral acute limb ischemia; may have preserved flow to one leg if eccentric
Thrombosis: underlying severe aortoiliac atherosclerosis, prior claudication history, gradual decompensation. Embolism: sudden onset, cardiac source (AFib, recent MI), no prior leg symptoms
Bilateral cold, pulseless legs; sensory and motor deficits; severe pain; absent femoral pulses bilaterally; may have shock, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia from muscle ischemia
Leriche syndrome is chronic aortoiliac occlusion (claudication, impotence, absent pulses); acute aortic occlusion is the sudden/acute counterpart with threatened limbs
Profound acidosis; hyperkalemia (muscle necrosis); acute kidney injury; myoglobinuria; coagulopathy; multiorgan failure. The systemic derangement often more dangerous than limb ischemia
CTA if patient stable (defines anatomy); often proceed directly to OR if diagnosis clear; shows complete aortic occlusion with absent flow distally
Bilateral femoral cutdowns with retrograde thromboembolectomy (Fogarty catheters); may need aortobifemoral bypass if underlying occlusive disease; fasciotomy often required
May attempt catheter-directed thrombolysis in selected cases; mechanical thrombectomy with aspiration; often requires hybrid approach
Release of toxic metabolites (K+, lactate, myoglobin) upon revascularization; can cause cardiac arrest, renal failure; may need temporary shunt/staged reperfusion or even amputation to save life
Mortality 30-50% even with treatment; higher with delayed presentation, profound acidosis, or irreversible ischemia; amputation rate 10-30%

learning_objectives: Define acute aortic occlusion and distinguish embolic from thrombotic
Recognize the severity - bilateral limb ischemia + systemic compromise
Understand reperfusion syndrome and its management
Know the high mortality despite treatment
clinical_pearls: Absent bilateral femoral pulses = acute aortic occlusion until proven otherwise
Systemic metabolic derangement often kills before limb is lost
Saddle embolus = look for atrial fibrillation or recent MI
Be prepared for hyperkalemia upon reperfusion
May need to amputate to save life if reperfusion syndrome severe
Mortality 30-50% - this is a vascular emergency
common_mistakes: Delaying surgery while obtaining extensive imaging
Not addressing cardiac source of embolism
